_header: Heaven bliss that all shall win
_description: Romance of Sir Tryamour, a fragment, parts of 10 folios — written in 12-line stanzas, aabccbddbeeb

BodEngPoetd208.First Lines:
…Þe kyng lowede welle hys queneffor scho was semly on to
                    sene…
BodEngPoetd208.Last Lines:
…Þus schul ȝe to hym sayI wold hym see Be my
                    fay…
BodEngPoetd208.Note: Corresponds to lines 25-1119, passim, of Cambridge UK,  Cambridge University Library Ff.2.38.
BodEngPoetd208.Editions:
Gibson,  S.,
                        ed.  
             “Colonel William E. Moss.” 
             Bodleian Library Record
         5:3 (1955): 156-66: 164.

CULFf238.First Lines:
Heven blys þat all schall wynneSchylde vs fro dedly
                    synne…
CULFf238.Last Lines:
…That euyr schall laste with owt mysAmen Amen for
                    charytee

McSparran,  Frances,  and  Pamela R. Robinson.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Cambridge University Library MS Ff.2.38.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

BodRawFrag.First Lines:
…And when they had saide alle that in stoureThe maide woulde
                    none but TriamoureThan the grete lordes there presentHome to Arragone
                    thay wenteThey were so stoute in stowre…
BodRawFrag.Last Lines:
…The Emperoure sayd withoute fayleSette a day of
                    bataileBy the assente…
BodRawFrag.Note:
No longer extant: see 
X 
             “J. O. Halliwell and the Bodleian.” 
             Bodleian Library Record
         2 (1946): 237-8, 237 (where it is
                    suggested the MS was stolen by Halliwell); 75 lines.
